intro: Carex engelmannii var. paddoensis, commonly known as the Paddo sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes grass-like plants known for their narrow, grass-like leaves and spike-like flower clusters. This variant is characterized by its dense, cylindrical inflorescence and is often found in moist, well-drained soils in wetlands or along stream banks. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and is adapted to temperate climates. Its botanical features make it an important component of riparian and wetland ecosystems.
